comments.author: DarkyGoesGaming

comments.text:
+MmeDefarge (Expose NYC Meth Labs) Nobody gives a rat's, ass' about you not 
liking bar soaps. You blamed bar soaps for diseases! That's a wicked'' and 
reprehensible'' comment'' on your part!! You are a vile'' creature!! You 
spread PANIC"" and FEAR!!
comments.author: Mike Rodriguez

comments.text:
+llGemini19 As I said, the developmental center was a crowded place full of 
compromised individuals with a high rate of infections.  Of course, bar 
soap wasn't the only factor in the spread of infection but it certainly 
didn't help.  It's not quite the same thing as having bar soap in a private 
clinic.  I've never in my lifetime, seen bar soap used in a hospital or 
nursing home which are already places with high rates of infections.  It's 
just my personal preference not to use bar soap at home as I find them very 
unpleasant to use and I'll never use them again.
comments.author: MmeDefarge (Expose NYC Meth Labs)

comments.text:
+MmeDefarge (Expose NYC Meth Labs) I mean just because of one isolated case 
that doesn't mean that the entirety of bar soaps are to blame. I use and 
have been using bar soaps for my whole life. My family all use it too. Hell 
even my doctor uses it in his office. It's possible that the rampant 
infection could have come from somewhere else and not the bar soap. It's 
never good to just assume things without reason. Unless you explicitly 
found the cause for the infection on the bar of soap, it's an assumption 
that you made that the cause of the infections was because of the soap. 
Trust me, bar soap is completely safe and there's no need to fear that the 
bacteria on it can really cause anything. Our bodies are pretty good about 
killing bad bacteria and infections.
comments.author: llGemini19

comments.text:
+MmeDefarge (Expose NYC Meth Labs) Says the stupid cunt! Who thinks soap is 
radioactive. Soap is soap! You stupid 'shit' slinger!! It's how it's 
incorrectly used:: not the soap itself! You dumb fat' lazy slob!!
comments.author: Mike Rodriguez

comments.text:
+Mike Rodriguez You obviously know nothing of hospitals.  Hospitals are and 
always have been infamous repositories of infection.  Bar soap in a 
hospital - that had to  be  early 20th century U.S. or even earlier.   
People used to think of hospitals as places where one went to die with good 
reason.  And you sir, are not only an ignorant fuck;  you're a troll.
comments.author: MmeDefarge (Expose NYC Meth Labs)

comments.text:
+MmeDefarge (Expose NYC Meth Labs) Bar soaps were used in hospitals for 
many years: way before bottled soaps started appearing! My great grandma 
worked in six hospitals!! She would put out the bars of soap! She was the 
cleaning lady!! Back then! Never once: was there any infections!! 
Development centres' have many issues going on! That's totally different! 
They created their own problems! Don't blame the soap! You are not very 
smart!! You dumb ASS!!
comments.author: Mike Rodriguez

comments.text:
+Mike Rodriguez Antibacterial soaps are not healty to use.  I've looked at 
bar soap under a microscope and it was dirty (not that you can see it with 
the naked eye).  I prefer not to wash with slimy, dirty bar soap; that's 
just my preference.

The rampant infections I'd see at the developmental center I once worked in 
were not normal.  That was a crowded place full of often compromised 
individuals prone to infections.  The use of bar soap was not appropriate 
there; bar soap has never been used in hospitals for good reasons.
comments.author: MmeDefarge (Expose NYC Meth Labs)

comments.text:
+MmeDefarge (Expose NYC Meth Labs) As you lather' you are rinsing' off 
anything bad' and the soap' actually becomes renewed' as fresh layers' 
become vibrant! We have used ivory soap bar' soap' for 76 years!! We never 
had one infection! All our children' grandchildren' too!!
comments.author: Mike Rodriguez

comments.text:
+Mike Rodriguez Dirt and bacteria are two different things.  Something can 
be soiled and still be relatively bacteria free.  I don't like washing with 
something which is already dirty.
comments.author: MmeDefarge (Expose NYC Meth Labs)

comments.text: +MmeDefarge (Expose NYC Meth Labs) Not! Antibacterial bar soap!
comments.author: Mike Rodriguez

comments.text:
+llGemini19 I just use plain liquid soap or liquid soap with moisturizers, 
no antibacterials.  Dirt can be seen on bar soap under a microscope even if 
you can't see it with the naked eye.  Years ago, I worked in a 
developmental center with mentally retarded children.  Bar soap was used 
throughout to make the atmosphere more "homelike".  Nosocomial infections 
were rampant in that place, unlike any other place I've ever seen.
comments.author: MmeDefarge (Expose NYC Meth Labs)

comments.text:
+MmeDefarge (Expose NYC Meth Labs) It's actually not dirty. As you lather 
it up it sheds off the first layer. That's what is used to lather your 
hands. Slimy and unpleasant? That's subjective, so it's definitely up to 
you. I'm just saying that bar soap is not bad at all to use and is actually 
better for your hands than anti basterial soap. Now if you use liquid soap 
that isn't antibacterial, that's fine and is completely up to you.
comments.author: llGemini19

comments.text:
+llGemini19 bar soap is also dirty, slimy and unpleasant to use; I'll stick 
with the liquid soap.
comments.author: MmeDefarge (Expose NYC Meth Labs)

comments.text:
You realize that not all bacteria is harmful right? Just because something 
has bacteria on it (which btw, EVERYTHING has bacteria on it. Yes, even you 
have bacteria on you AND inside you EVEN after a shower!) doesn't mean it's 
bad. There's A TON of harmless bacteria all around us that we constantly 
breath in and out, eat, touch, smell, etc. I promise you the bacteria on 
that bar of soap is completely and utterly harmless.
comments.author: llGemini19

comments.text: http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/3402545
comments.author: John Doe

comments.text: I say toss those "onion bags", and use a fresh clean washcloth every time.﻿
comments.author: Anna Falactica

comments.text:
I knew all of these except the tooth enamel one and frankly I don't believe 
it for a moment. That stuff is an extremely stiff mineral, it can't just 
become soft in a few minutes and then harden up a few minutes later. Brush 
after eating, before the bacteria have time to saturate your mouth with 
lactic acid.

Don't use shower poofies at all (those things people call luffas that 
aren't luffas), and don't use luffas, either. Shower poofies are remarkably 
ineffective at scrubbing your body. Luffas are decent for scrubbing but you 
can get the same effect from a cheap rag, and that cleans much easier and 
lasts much longer. Also, the rag is gentler to your skin while still 
getting the grime off.

Antibacterial soap isn't simply not more effective than regular soap, it is 
actually bad for your health and the health of others around you if you use 
it on a regular basis. Those soaps contain triclosan, a substance that 
lingers on your skin and makes it difficult for bacteria to grow on your 
skin. This negatively affects the bacterial populations on your skin and 
can lead to bacterial imbalances, infections, or worse, infectious bacteria 
that resist triclosan--"superbugs". Antibacterial soap should only be used 
occasionally when you expect to be making physical contact with a lot of 
people you don't know, or are working with food to be served to the public. 
If you do this on a regular basis, don't use antibacterial soap, use latex 
or nitrile gloves.﻿
